How, dost call me rogue? Fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Part 'em, master, part 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: This is meere frailty, brethren, be content.
Fryar Barnardine goe you with Ithimore.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: You know my mind, let me alone with him;
Why does he goe to thy house, let him begone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I'le giue him something and so stop his mouth.
I neuer heard of any man but he
Malign'd the order of the Iacobines:
But doe you thinke that I beleeue his words?
Why Brother you conuerted Abigall;
And I am bound in charitie to requite it,
And so I will, oh Iocome, faile not but come.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry,
SP.L: But Barabas who shall be your godfathers,
For presently you shall be shriu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Marry the Turke shall be one of my godfathers,
But not a word to any of your Couent.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: I warrant thee, Barabas. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: So now the feare is past, and I am safe:
For he that shriu'd her is within my house,
What if I murder'd him e're Iocoma comes?
Now I haue such a plot for both their liues,
As neuer Iew nor Christian knew the like:
One turn'd my daughter, therefore he shall dye;
The other knowes enough to haue my life,
Therefore 'tis not requisite he should liue.
But are not both these wise men to suppose
That I will leaue my house, my goods, and all,
To fast and be well whipt; I'le none of that.
Now Fryar Bernardine I come to you,
I'le feast you, lodge you, giue you faire words,
And after that, I and my trusty Turke —
No more but so: it must and shall be done.
Ithimore, tell me, is the Fryar asleepe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Yes; and I know not what the reason is
Doe what I can he will not strip himselfe,
Nor goe to bed, but sleepes in his owne cloth
I feare me he mistrusts what we intend.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: No, 'tis an order which the Fryars vse:
Yet if he knew our meanings, could he scape?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: No, none can heare him, cry he ne're so loud.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Why true, therefore did I place him there:
The other Chambers open towards the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: You loyter, master, wherefore stay we thus?
Oh how I long to see him shake his heeles.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Come on, sirra, off with your girdle, make a hansom noose;
Fryar awake.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: What doe you meane to strangle me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Yes, 'cause you vse to confesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Blame not vs but the prouerb, Confes & be hang'd
Pull hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: What, will you saue my life?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pull hard, I say, you would haue had my goods.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I, and our liues too therefore pull amaine.
'Tis neatly done, Sir, here's no print at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Then is it as it should be, take him vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Nay, Mr. be ul'd by me a little; so, let him leane
Vpon his staffe; excellent, he stands as if he were begging of Bacon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Who would not thinke but that this Fryar liu'd?
What time a night is't now, sweet Ithimore?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Towards one.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Then will not Iocoma long from hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioco.
SP.L: This is the houre wherein I shall proceed;
Oh happy houre, wherein I shall conuert
An Infidell, and bring his gold into our treasury.
But soft, is not this Bernardine? it is;
And vnderstanding I should come this way,
Stands here a purpose, meaning me some wrong,
And intercept my going to the Iew; Bernardine;
Wilt thou not speake? thou think'st I see thee no;
Away I'de wish thee, and let me goe by:
No, wilt thou not? nay then I'le force my way;
And see staffe stands ready for the purpose:
As thou lik'st that, stop me another time.

DIV1.STAGE: Strike him, he fals. Enter Barabas.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Why how now Iocoma, what hast thou done?
Why stricken him that would haue stroke at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Who is it Bernardine? now out alas, he is slaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I, Mr. he's slain; look how his brains drop out on's nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioco.
SP.L: Good sirs I haue don't, but nobody knowes it but
You two, I may escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: So might my man and I hang with you for com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: No, let vs beare him to the Magistrates.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioco.
SP.L: Good Barabas let me goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: No, pardon me, the Law must haue his course.
I must be forc'd to giue in euidence,
That being importun'd by this Berardin
To be a Christian, I shut him out,
And there he sate: now I to keepe my word,
And giue my goods and substance to your house,
Was vp thus early; with intent to goe
Vnto your Friery, because you staid.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Fie vpon 'em, Mr. will you turne Christian, when
Holy Friars turne deuils and murder one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: No, for this example I'le remaine a Iew:
Heauen blesse me; what, a Fryar a murderer?
When shall you see a Iew commit the like?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Why a Turke could a done no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: To morrow is the Sessions; you shall to it.
Come Ithimore, let's helpe to take him hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioco.
SP.L: Villaines, I am a sacred person, touch me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: The Law shall touch you, we'll but lead you, we
'Las I could weepe at your calamity.
Take in the staffe too, for that must be showne:
Law wils that each particular be knowne. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Pilia-borza, didst thou meet with Ithimore?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: And didst thou deliuer my letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: And what think'st thou, will he come?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: I think so, and yet I cannot tell, for at the reading of
The letter, he look'd like a man of another world.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: That such a base slaue as he should be saluted by such
A tall man as I am, from such a beautifull dame as you.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: And what said he?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Not a wise word, only gaue me a nod, as who shold say, Is it euen so; and so I left him, being driuen to a Non-plus at the critical aspect of my terrible countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.P: Vpon mine owne free-hold within 40 foot of the Gallowes, conning his neck-verse I take it, looking of a Fryars Execution, whom I saluted with an old hempen prouerb, Hidie tibi, cras mihi, and so I left him to the mercy Of the Hangman: but the Exercise being done, see where He comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.P: I neuer knew a man take his death so patiently as This Fryar; he was ready to leape off e're the halter was About his necke; and when the Hangman had put on his Hempen Tippet, he made such haste to his prayers, as if Hee had had another Cure to serue; well, goe whither He will, I'le be none of his followers in haste:
SP.L: And now I thinke on't, going to the execution, a fellow
Met me with a muschatoes like a Rauens wing, and
A Dagger with a hilt like a warming-pan, and he
Gaue me a letter from one Madam Bellamira,
Saluting me in such sort as if he had meant to make
Cleane my Boots with his lips; the effect was, that
I should come to her house, I wonder what the reason is;
It may be she sees more in me than I can find in
My selfe: for she writes further, that she loues me
Euer since she saw me, and who would not requie such
Loue hee's her house, and here she comes, and now
Would I were gone, I am not worthy to looke vpon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilia.
SP.L: This is the Gentleman you writ to.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Gentleman, he flouts me, what gentry can be in a
Poore Turke of ten pence? I'le be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Is't not a sweet fac'd youth, Pilia?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Agen, sweet youth; did not you, Sir, bring the sweet
Youth a letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilia.
SP.L: I did Sir, and from this Gentlewoman, who as my
Selfe, & the rest of the family, stand or fall at your seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Though womans modesty should hale me backe,
I can with-hold no longer; welcome sweet loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Now am I cleane, or rather fouly out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Whither so soone?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I'le goe steale some mony from my Master to
Make me hansome:
Pray pardon me, I must goe see a ship discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Canst thou be so vnkind to leaue me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilia.
SP.L: And ye did but know how she loues you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Nay, I care not how much she loues me;
Sweet Allamira, would I had my Masters wealth for thy sake:

SP.SPEAKER: Pilia.
SP.L: And you can haue it, Sir, and if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: If 'twere aboue ground I could, and would haue it;
But hee hides and buries it vp as Partridges doe
Their egges, vnder the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: And is't not possible to find it out?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: By no meanes possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: What shall we doe with this base villaine then?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Let me alone, doe but you speake him faire:
But you know some secrets of the Iew, which if they were
Reueal'd, would doe him harme.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I, and such as — Goe to, no more,
I'le make him send me half he has, & glad he scapes so too.
Pen and Inke:
I'le write vnto him, we'le haue mony strait.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil,
SP.L: Send for a hundred Crownes at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Ten hundred thousand crownes,— Mr. Barabas.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Write not so submissiuely, but threatning him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Sirra Barabas, send me a hundred crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Put in two hundred at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I charge thee send me 300 by this bearer, and this
Shall be your warrant; if you doe not, no more but so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Tell him you will confesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Otherwise I'le confesse all, vanish and returne in a Twinckle.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Let me alone, I'le vse him in his kinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Hang him Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Now, gentle Ithimore, lye in my lap.
Where are my Maids? prouide a running Banquet;
Send to the Merchant, bid him bring me silkes,
Shall Ithimore my loue goe in such rags?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: And bid the Ieweller come hither too.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: I haue no husband, sweet, I'le marry thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Content, but we will leaue this paltry land,
And saile from hence to Greece, to louely Greece,
I'le be thy Iason, thou my golden Fleece;
Where painted Carpets o're the meads are hurl'd,
And Bacchus vineyards ore-spread the world:
Where Woods and Forrests goe in goodly greene,
I'le be Adonis, thou shalt be Loues Queene.
The Meads, the Orchards, and the Primrose lanes,
Instead of Sedge and Reed, beare Sugar Canes:
Thou in those Groues, by Dis aboue,
Shalt liue with me and be my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Whiher will I not goe with gentle Ithimore?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: How now? hast thou the gold?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Yes.
But came it freely, did the Cow giue down her milk freely?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: At reading of the letter, he star'd & stamp'd, & turnd
Aside, I tooke him by the sterd, & look'd vpon him thus;
Told him he were best to send it, then he hug'd & imbrac'd me

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Rather for feare then loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Then like a Iew he laugh'd & jeer'd, and told me he
lou'd me for your sake, & said what a faithfull seruant you had bin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: The more villaine he to keep me thus:
Here's goodly 'parrell, is there not?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: To conclude, he gaue me ten crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: But ten? I'le not leaue him worth a gray groat, giue
Me a Reame of paper, we'll haue a kingdome of gold for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Write for 500 Crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Sirra Iew, as you loue your life send me 500 crowns,
And giue the Bearer 100. Tell him I must hau't.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: I warrant your worship shall hau't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith,
SP.L: And if he aske why I demand so much, tell him,
I scorne to write a line vnder a hundred crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Yo'd make a rich Poet, Sir. I am gone. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Take thou the mony, spend it for my sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: 'Tis not thy mony, but thy selfe I weigh:
Thus Bellamira esteemes of gold;
But thus of thee. — Kisse him. —

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: That kisse againe; she runs diuision of my lips.
What an eye she casts on me?
It twinckles like a Starre.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Come my deare loue, let's in and sleepe together.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Oh that ten thousand nights were put in one,
That wee might sleepe seuen yeeres together afore
We wake.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Come Amorous wag, first banquet and then sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Barabas send me 300 Crownes.
Plaine Barabas: oh that wicked Curtezane!
He was not wont to call me Barabas.
Or else I will confesse: I, there it goes:
But if I get him Coupe de Gorge, for that
He sent a shaggy totter'd staring slaue,
That when he speakes, drawes out his grisly beard,
And winds it twice or thrice about his eare;
Whose face has bin a grind-stone for mens swords,
His hands are hackt, some fingers cut quite off;
Who when he speakes, grunts like a hog, and looks
Like one that is imploy'd in Catzerie,
And crosbiting such a Rogue
As is the husband to a hundred whores:
And I by him must send three hundred crownes.
Well, my hope is, he will not stay there still;
And when he comes: Oh that he were but here!

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Iew, I must ha more gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Why wantst thou any of thy tale?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: No; but 300 will not serue his turne.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Not serue his turne, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: No Sir; and therefore I must haue 500 more.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I'le rather —

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Oh good words, Sir, and send it you were best, see,
There's his letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Might he not as well come as send; pray bid him
Come & fetch it, what hee writes for you, ye shall haue streight.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: I, and the rest too, or else —

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I must make this villaine away: please you dine
With me, Sir, & you shal be most hartily poyson'd. aside

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: No god-a-mercy, shall I haue these crownes?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I cannot doe it, I haue lost my keyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Oh, if that be all, I can picke ope your locks.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Or climbe vp to my Counting-house window:
You know my meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: I know enough, and therfore talke not to me of your
Counting-house, the gold, or know Iew it is in my power to hang thee

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I am betraid.
'Tis not 500 Crownes that I esteeme,
I am not mou'd at that: this angers me,
That he who knowes I loue him as my selfe
Should write in this imperious vaine? why Sir,
You know I haue no childe, and vnto whom
Should I leaue all but vnto Ithimore?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Here's many words but no crownes; the crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Commend me to him, Sir, most humbly,
And vnto your good mistris as vnknowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Speake, shall I haue 'vm, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Sir here they are.
Oh that I should part with so much gold!
Here take 'em, fellow, with as good a will —
—As I nd see thee hang'd; oh, loue stops my breath:
Neuer lou'd man seruant as I doe Ithimore.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: I know it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pray when, Sir, shall I see you at my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Soone enough to your cost, Sir:
Fare you well. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Nay to thine owne cost, villaine, if thou com'st.
Was euer Iew tormented as I am?
To haue a shag-rag knaue to come
300 Crownes, and then 500 Crownes?
Well, I must seeke a meanes to rid 'em all,
And presently: for in his villany
He will tell all he knowes and I shall dye for't. I haue it.
I will in some disguize goe see the slaue,
And how the villaine reuels with my gold. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: I'le pledge thee, loue, and therefore drinke it off.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Saist thou me so? haue at it; and doe you heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Goe to, it shall be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Of that condition I wil drink it vp; here's to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Nay, I'le haue all or none.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: There, if thou lou'st me doe not leaue a drop.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Loue thee, fill me three glasses.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Three and fifty dozen, I'le pledge thee,

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Knauely spoke, and like a Knight at Armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Hey Riuo Castiliano, a man's a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Now to the Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Ha to the Iew, and send me mony you were best.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: What wudst thou doe if he should send thee none?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Doe nothing; but I know what I know,
He's a murderer.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: I had not thought he had been so braue a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: You knew Mathias and the Gouernors son, he and
I kild 'em both, and yet neuer touch'd 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Oh brauely done.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I carried the broth that poyson'd the Nuns, and he
And I snicle hand too fast, strangled a Fryar.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: You two alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: We two, and 'twas neuer knowne, nor neuer shall
Be for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: This shall with me vnto the Gouernor.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: And fit it should: but first let's ha more gold
Come gentle Ithimore, lye in my lap.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Loue me little, loue me long, let musicke rumble,
Whilst I in thy incoomy lap doe tumble.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Barabas with a Lute, disguis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: A French Musician, come let's heare your skill?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Must tuna my Lute for sound, twang twang first.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Wilt drinke French-man, here's to thee with a —
Pox on this drunken hick-vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Gramercy Mounsier.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Prethe, Pilia-borza, bid the Fidler giue me
The posey in his hat there.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Sirra, you must giue my mistris your posey.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: A voustre commandemente Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: How sweet, my Ithimore, the flowers smell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Like thy breath, sweet-hart, no violet like 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Foh, me thinkes they stinke like a Holly-Hoke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: So, now I am reueng'd vpon 'em all.
The scent thereof was death, I poyson'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Play, Fidler, or I'le cut your cats guts into chitterlins
Pardona moy, be no in tune yet; so now, now all be in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Giue him a crowne, and fill me out more wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: There's two crownes for thee, play.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: How liberally the villain giues me mine own gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Me thinkes he fingers very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: So did you when you stole my gold. aside

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: How swift he runnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You run swifter when yon threw my gold out of
My Window. aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Musician, hast beene in Malta long?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Two, three, foure month Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Dost not know a Iew, one Barabas?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Very mush, Mounsier, you no be his man.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: His man?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I scorne the Peasant, tell him so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: He knowes it already.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: 'Tis a strange thing of that Iew, he liues vpon
Pickled Grashoppers, and sau'd Mushrumbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What a slaue's this?
The Gouernour feeds not as I doe. aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: He neuer put on cleane shirt since he was circumcis'd

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Oh raskall! I change my selfe twice a day. aside

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: The Hat he weares, Iudas left vnder the Elder
When he hang'd himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: 'Twas sent me for a present from the great Cham.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: A masty slaue he is;
Whether now, Fidler?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pardona moy, Mounsier, we be no well. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Farewell Fidler: One letter more to the Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Prethe sweet loue, one more, and write it sharp.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: No, I'le send by word of mouth now;
Bid him deliuer thee a thousand Crownes, by the same
Token, that the Nuns lou'd Rice, that Fryar Bernardine
Slept in his owne clothes,
Any of 'em will doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Let me alone to vrge it now I know the meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: The meaning has a meaning; come let's in:
To vndoe a Iew is charity, and not sinne Exeunt.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus Quintus.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: NOw, Gentlemen, betake you to your Armes,
And see that Malta be well fortifi'd;
And it behoues you to be resolute;
For Calymath hauing houer'd here so long,
Will winne the Towne, or dye before the wals.

SP.SPEAKER: Kni.
SP.L: And dye he shall, for we will neuer yeeld.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Oh bring vs to the Gouernor.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Away with her, she is a Curtezane.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: What e're I am, yet Gouernor heare me speake;
I bring thee newes by whom thy sonne was slaine:
Mathias did it not, it was the Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Pil.
SP.L: Who, besides the slaughter of these Gentlemen,
Poyson'd his owne daughter and the Nuns,
Strangled a Fryar, and I know not what
Mischiefe beside.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Had we but proofe of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Strong proofe, my Lord, his man's now at my
Lodging that was his Agent, he'll confesse it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Goe fetch him straight, I alwayes fear'd that Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I'le goe alone, dogs do not hale me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Nor me neither, I cannot out-run you Constable, oh my belly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: One dram of powder more had made all sure,
What a damn'd slaue was I?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Make fires, heat irons, let the racke be fetch'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Kni.
SP.L: Nay stay, my Lord, 'tmay be he will confesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Confesse; what meane you, Lords, who should confesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Thou and thy Turk; 'twas you that slew my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: Gilty, my Lord, I confesse; your sonne and Mathias
Were both contracted vnto Abigall,
Forg'd a counterfeit challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Iew.
SP.L: Who carried that challenge?

SP.SPEAKER: Ith.
SP.L: I carried it, I confesse, but who writ it?
Marry euen he that strangled Bernardine, poyson'd the
Nuns, and his owne daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Away with him, his sight is death to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: For what, you men of Malta, heare me speake;
Shee is a Curtezane and he a theefe,
And he my bondman, let me haue law,
For none of this can preiudice my life:

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Once more away with him; you shall haue law.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Deuils doe your worst, I liue in spite of you.
As these haue spoke so be it to their soules:
I hope the poyson'd flowers will worke anon. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mater.
SP.L: Was my Mathias murder'd by the Iew?
Ferueze, 'twas thy sonne that murder'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Be patient, gentle Madam, it was he,
He forged the daring challenge made them fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Where is the Iew, where is that murderer?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: In prison till the Law has past on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Offi.
SP.L: My Lord, the Curtezane and her man are dead;
So is the Turke, and Barabas the Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Offi.
SP.L: Dead, my Lord, and here they bring his body.

SP.SPEAKER: Bosco.
SP.L: This sudden death of his is very strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Wonder not at it, Sir, the heauens are iust
Their deaths were like their liues, then think not of 'em
Since they are dead, let them be buried.
For the Iewes body, throw that o're the wals,
To be a prey for Vultures and wild beasts.
So, now away and fortifie the Towne. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What, all alone? well fare sleepy drinke.
I'le be reueng'd on this accursed Towne;
For by my meanes Calymath shall enter in.
I'le helpe to slay their children and their wiues,
To fire the Churches, pull their houses downe,
Take my goods too, and seize vpon my lands:
I hope to see the Gouernour a slaue,
And, rowing in a Gally, whipt to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Whom haue we there, a spy?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Yes, my good Lord, one that can spy a place
Where you may enter, and surprize the Towne:
My name is Barabas; I am a Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Art thou that Iew whose goods we heard were sold
For Tribute-mony?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: The very same, my Lord:
And since that time they haue hir'd a slaue my man
To accuse me of a thousand villanies:
I was imprison'd, but scap'd their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Didst breake prison?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: No, no:
I dranke of Poppy and cold mandrake juyce;
And being asleepe, belike they thought me dead,
And threw me o're the wals so, or how else,
The Iew is here, and rests at your command.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: 'Twas brauely done: but tell me, Barabas,
Canst thou, as thou reportest, make Malta ours?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Feare not, my Lord, for here against the Truce,
The rocke is hollow, and of purpose digg'd,
To make a passage for the running streames
And common channels of the City.
Now whilst you giue assault vnto the wals,
I'le lead 500 souldiers through the Vault,
And rise with them i'th middle of the Towne,
Open the gates for you to enter in,
And by this meanes the City is your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: If this be true, I'le make thee Gouernor.

SP.SPEAKER: Iew.
SP.L: And if it be not true, then let me dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Thou'st doom'd thy selfe, assault it presently.

DIV1.STAGE: Alarmes. Enter Turkes, Barabas, Gouernour, and Knights prisoners.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Now vaile your pride you captiue Christians,
And kneele for mercy to your conquering foe:
Now where's the hope you had of haughty Spaine?
Ferneze, speake, had it not beene much better
To kept thy promise then be thus surpriz'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: What should I say, we are captiues and must yeeld.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: I, villains, you must yeeld, and vnder Turkish yokes
Shall groning beare the burthen of our ire;
And Barabas, as erst we promis'd thee,
For thy desert we make the Gouernor,
Vse them at thy discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Thankes, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Oh fatall day to fall into the hands
Of such a Traitor and vnhallowed Iew!
What greater misery could heauen inflict?

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: 'Tis our command: and Barabas, we giue
To guard thy person, these our Ianizaries:
Intreat them well, as we haue vsed thee.
And now, braue Bashawes, come, wee'll walke about
The ruin'd Towne, and see the wracke we made:
Farewell braue Iew, farewell great Barabas. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: May all good fortune follow Calymath.
And now, as entrance to our safety,
To prison with the Gouernour and these
Captaines, his consorts and confederates.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Oh villaine, Heauen will be reueng'd on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: A way, no more, let him not trouble me.
Thus hast thou gotten, by thy policie,
No simple place, no small authority,
I now am Gouernour of Malta; true,
But Malta hates me, and in hating me
My life's in danger, and what boots it thee
Poore Barabas, to be the Gouernour,
When as thy life shall be at their command?
No, Barabas, this must be look'd into;
And since by wrong thou got'st Authority,
Maintaine it brauely by firme policy,
At least vnprofitably lose it not:
For he that liueth in Authority,
And neither gets him friends, nor fils his bags,
Liues like the Asse that Aesope speaketh of,
That labours with a load of bread and wine,
And leaues it off to snap on Thistle tops:
But Barabas will be more circumspect.
Begin betimes, Occasion's bald behind,
Slip not thine oportunity, for feare too late
Thou seek'st for much, but canst not compasse it
Within here.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: My Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I, Lord, thus aues will learne
Now Gouernor stand by there, wait within,
This is the reason that I sent for thee;
Thou seest thy life, and Malta's happinesse,
Are at my Arbitrament; and Barabas
At his discretion may dispose of both:
Now tell me, Gouernor, and plainely too,
What thinkst thou shall become of it and thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: This; Barabas, since things are in thy power,
I see no reason but of Malta's wracke,
Nor hope of thee but extreme cruelty,
Nor feare I death, nor will I flatter thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Gouernor, good words, be not so furious;
'Tis not thy life which can auale me ought,
Yet you doe liue, and liue for me you shall:
And as for Malta's ruine, thinke you no
'Twere slender policy for Barabas
To dispossesse himselfe of such a place?
For sith, as once you said, within this Ile
In Malta here, that I haue got my goods,
And in this City still haue had successe,
And now at length am growne your Governor,
Your selues shall see it shall not be forgot:
For as a friend not knowne, but in distresse,
I'le reare vp Malta now remedilesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Will Barabas recouer Malta's losse?
Will Barabas be good to Christians?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What wilt thou giue me, Gouernor, to procure
A dissolution of the slauish Bands
Wherein the Turke hath yoak'd your land and you?
What will you giue me if I render you
The life of Calymath, surprize his men,
And in an out house of the City shut
His souldiers, till I haue consum'd 'em all with fire?
What will you giue him that procureth this?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Doe but bring this to passe which thou pretendest,
Deale truly with vs as thou intimatest,
And I will send amongst the Citizens
And by my letters priuately procure
Great summes of mony for thy recompence:
Nay more, doe this, and liue thou Gouernor still.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Nay, doe thou this, Ferneze, and be free;
Gouernor, I enlarge thee, liue with me,
Goe walke about the City, see thy friends:
Tush, send not letters to 'em, goe thy selfe,
And let me see what mony thou canst make;
Here is my hand that I'le set Malta free:
And thus we cat it: To a solemne feast
I will inuite young Selim-Calymath,
Where be thou present onely to performe
One stratagem that I'le impart to thee,
Wherein no danger shall betide thy life,
And I will warrant Malta free for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Here is my hand, beleeue me, Barabas,
I will be there, and doe as thou desirest;
When is the time?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Gouernor, presently.
For Callymath, when he hath view'd the Towne,
Will take his leaue and saile toward, Ottoman,

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Then will I, Barabas, about this coyne,
And bring it with me to thee in the euening.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Doe so, but faile not; now farewell Ferneze
And thus farre roundly goes the businesse:
Thus louing neither, will I liue with both,
Making a profit of my policie;
And he from whom my most aduantage comes,
Shall be my friend.
This is the life we Iewes are vs'd to lead;
And reason too, for Christians doe the like:
Well, now about effecting this deuice:
First to surprize great Selims souldiers,
And then to make prouision for the feast,
That at one instant all things may be done,
My policie detests preuention:
To what euent my secret purpose driues,
I know; and they shall witnesse with their liues. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Thus haue we view'd the City, seene the sacke,
And cau'd the ruines to be new repair'd,
Which with our Bombards shot and Basiliske,
We rent in sunder at our entry:
And now I see the Scituation,
And how secure this conquer'd Iland stands
Inuiron'd with the mediterranean Sea,
Strong contermin'd with other petty Iles;
And toward Calabria back'd by Sicily,
Two lofty Turrets that command the Towne.
When Siracusian Dionisius reign'd;
I wonder how it could be conquer'd thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: From Barabas, Malta's Gouernor, I bring
A message vnto mighty Calymath;
Hearing his Soueraigne was bound for Sea,
To saile to Turkey, to great Ottamon,
He humbly would intreat your Maiesty
To come and see his homely Citadell,
And banquet with him e're thou leau'st the Ile.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: To banquet with him in his Citadell,
I eare me, Messenger, to feast my traine
Within a Towne of warre so lately pillag'd,
Will be too costly and too troublesome:
Yet would I gladly visit Barabas.
For well has Barabas desern'd of vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: Selim, for that, thus saith the Gouernor,
That he hath in store a Pearle so big,
So precious, and withall so orient,
As be it valued but indifferently,
The price thereof will serue to entertaine
Selim and all his souldiers for a month
Therefore he humbly would intreat your Highnesse
Not to depart till he has feasted you.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: I cannot feast my men in Malta wals,
Except he place his Tables in the streets.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: Know, Selim, that there is a monastery
Which standeth as an out-house to the Towne;
There will he banquet them, but thee at home,
With all thy Bashawes and braue followers.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Well, tell the Gouernor we grant his suit,
Wee'll in this Summer Euening feast with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: I shall, my Lord, Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: And now, bold Bashawes, let vs to our Tents,
And meditate how we may grace vs best
To solemnize our Gouernors great feast. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: In this, my Countrimen, be rul'd by me,
Haue speciall care that no man sally forth
Till you shall heare a Culuerin discharg'd
By him that beares the Linstocke, kindled thus;
Then issue out and come to rescue me,
For happily I shall be in distresse,
Or you released of this seruitude.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Kni.
SP.L: Rather then thus to liue as Turkish thrals,
What will we not aduenture?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: On then, begone.

SP.SPEAKER: Kni:
SP.L: Farewell graue Gouernor.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter with a Hammar aboue, very busie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: How stand the cords? How hang these hinges, fast?
Are all the Cranes and Pulleyes sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: All fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Leaue nothing loose, all leueld to my mind.
Why now I see that you haue Art indeed.
There, Carpenters, diuide that gold amongst you:
Goe swill in bowles of Sacke and Muscadine:
Downe to the Cellr, taste of all my wines.

SP.SPEAKER: Carp.
SP.L: We shall, my Lord, and thanke you: Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: And if you like them, drinke your fill and dye:
For so I liue, perish may all the world.
Now Selim-Calymath returne me word
That thou wilt come, and I am satisfied.
Now sirra, what, will he come?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: He will; and has commanded all his men
To come ashore, and march through Malta streets,
That thou maist feast them in thy Citadell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Then now are all things as my wish wud haue 'em,
There wanteth nothing but the Gouernors pelfe,
And see he brings it: Now, Gouernor, the summe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gou.
SP.L: With free consent a hundred thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pounds saist thou, Goueror, wel since it is no more
I'le satisfie my selfe with that; nay, keepe it still,
For if I keepe not promise, trust not me.
And Gouernour, now partake my policy:
First for his Army, they are sent before,
Enter'd the Monastery, and vnderneath
In seuerall places are field-pieces pitch'd,
Bombards, whole Barrels full of Gunpowder,
That on the sudden shall disseuer it,
And batter all the stones about their eares,
Whence none can possibly escape aliue:
Now as for Calymath and his consorts,
Here haue I made a dainty Gallery,
The floore whereof, this Cable being cut,
Doth fall asunder; so that it doth sinke
Into a deepe pit past recouery.
Here, hold that knife, and when thou seest he comes,
And with his Bashawes shall be blithely set,
A warning-peece shall be shot off from the Tower,
To giue thee knowledge when to cut the cord,
And fire the house; say, will not this be braue?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Oh excellent! here, hold thee, Barabas,
I trust thy word, take what I promis'd thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: No, Gouernor, I'le satisfie thee first,
Thou shalt not liue in doubt of any thing.
Stand close, for here they come: why, is not this
A kingly kinde of trade to purchase Townes
By treachery, and sell 'em by deceit?
Now tell me, worldlings, vnderneath the summe,
If greater falshood euer hs bin done.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Come, my Companion-Bashawes, see I pray
How busie Barrabas is there aboue
To entertaine vs in his Gallery;
Let vs salute him, Saue thee, Barabas.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Welcome great Calymath.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: How the slaue jeeres at him?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Will't please thee, mighty Selim-Calymath,
To ascend our homely stayres?

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: I, Barabas, come Bashawes, attend.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Stay, Calymath;
For I will shew thee greater curtesie
Then Barabas would haue affoorded thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Kni.
SP.L: Sound a charge there. A charge, the cable cut, A Caldron discouered.

SP.SPEAKER: Cal.
SP.L: How now, what means this

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Helpe, helpe me, Christians, helpe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: See Calymath, this was deuis'd for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Treason, treason Bashawes, flye.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: No, Selim, doe not flye;
See his end first, and flye then if thou canst.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Oh helpe me, Selim, helpe me, Christians.
Gouernour, why stand you all so pittilesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Should I in pitty of thy plaints or thee,
Accursed Barabas; base Iew relent:
No, thus I'le see thy treachery repaid,
But wish thou hadst behau'd thee otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You will not helpe me then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: No, villaine, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: And villaines, know you cannot helpe me now.
Then Barabas breath forth thy latest fate,
And in the fury of thy torments, striue
To end thy life with resolution:
Know, Gouernor, 'twas I that slew thy sonne;
I fram'd the challenge that did make them meet
Know, Calymath, I aym'd thy ouerthrow,
And had I but escap'd this stratagem,
I would haue brought confusion on you all,
Damn'd Christians, dogges, and Turkish Infidels;
But now begins the extremity of heat
To pinch me with intolerable pangs:
Dye life, flye soule, tongue curse thy ill and dye:

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Tell me, you Christians, what doth this portend?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: This traine he laid to haue intrap'd thy life;
Now Selim note the vnhallowed deeds of Iewes:
Thus he determin'd to haue handled thee,
But I haue rather chose to saue thy life.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Was this the banquet he prepar'd for vs?
Let's hence, lest further mischiefe be pretended.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Nay, Selim, stay, for since we haue the here,
We will not let thee part so suddenly:
Besides, if we should let thee goe, all's one,
Nor with thy Gallyes couldst thou not get hence,
Without fresh men to rigge and furnish them.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Tush, Gouernor, take thou no care for that,
My men are all aboord,
And doe attend my comming there by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Why hardst thou not the trumpet sound a charge?

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Yes, what of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Why then the house was fir'd,
Blowne vp, and all thy souldiers massacred.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Oh monstrous treason!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: A Iewe curtesie:
For he that did by treason worke our fall,
By treason hath deliuered thee to vs:
Know therefore, till thy father hath made good
The ruines done to Malta and to vs,
Thou canst not part: for Malta shall be freed,
Or Selim ne're returne to Ottamen.

SP.SPEAKER: Caly.
SP.L: Nay rather, Christians, let me goe to Turkey
In person there to meditate your peace;
To keepe me here will nought aduantage you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.L: Content thee, Calymath, here thou must stay,
And liue in Malia prisoner; for come cal he world
To rescue thee, so will we guard vs now
sooner shall they drinke the Ocean dry,
Then conquer Malta, or endanger vs.
So march away, and let due praise be giuen
Neither to Fate nor Fottune, but to Heauen.
